title: Lloyd Austin Receives Waiver Allowing Him to Become Defense Chief
sub_head: Lawmakers’ action paves the way for confirmation of first Black defense secretary
body:
Lawmakers approved a resolution on Thursday allowing Lloyd Austin, a retired Army general, to hold the civilian post of defense secretary, clearing the way for his confirmation to the job.
If confirmed by senators as expected on Friday, Mr. Austin, 67 years old, will become the Defense Department’s first Black secretary.
Federal law requires any military officer who has been in civilian life for less than seven years to obtain a congressional waiver to serve as defense secretary, a requirement meant to safeguard the tradition of civilian control. Mr. Austin retired from the Army in 2016.
The House approved the waiver on a 326 to 78 vote. The Senate waiver vote was 69 to 27.
Retired Marine Corps Gen. Jim Mattis, former President Donald Trump’s first defense secretary, required a congressional waiver in 2017. Before Mr. Mattis, the only general ever to have received such a waiver was Gen. George Marshall, who served as defense chief 70 years ago.
